column4: Hello, I'm running a linux server and running into issues with directory permissions. Are directories like temp/ required to have 777 permission to allow the server to write to them? I always though 777 was very unsecured
/tmp has 1777 (sticky bit set) which is ok, other shouldn't need 777
Alright, what about logs/?
no way
How could I get around "not writeable for the webserver" then?
For logs/ that is
chgrp the dir to www-data, 775 is fine then
ah, you don't speak about /var/log?
No, its a directory within the software I'm trying to run on the server (roundcube) and it keeps throwing errors for both /temp and /logs
and only make those really needed dirs writeable, all other 755
Right, I knew that much
i misread you, thought you talk about /tmp etc...  give www-data limited write-access to those dirs it really needs to write. that should be fine
Alright, so I'll just chmod 777 those two directories then, I just wasn't sure if that was the solution, thanks.
not 777, chown all the stuff user:www-data   with 755   and chmod 775 those dirs
you don't want to have your webserver have writeaccess to all dirs/files
I understand what your saying, I'm just not sure how to actually do it... if I add a new group, doesn't httpd then need to run under that group so that it has the same permissions?
www-data IS the group apache/httpd runs as
Ah
Is the group made by default because I had to add it for it to recognize it?
its a systemgroup, created when installing apache or other webservers
Hmm, my httpd is actually running as root it shows, with the sub processes running as "apache" user
